title: Will the Republican candidate for president win the party's nomination on the first ballot, at the party's convention in July?
preds:
According to the general news, 538.com, PredictIt.com, and GJP consensus. 
I think Pence will unite the Republican Party and strengthens the Republican ticket.
The "Stop Trump" effort failed to sway the Repub Rules Committee. Relevant CNN article: http://www.cnn.com/2016/07/14/politics/republican-rules-delegates-trump/

The #NeverTrump movement was effectively crushed. Their tactics with the Rules Committee failed.   Notably, prominent GOP figures such as former presidents George H. W. Bush, Senior and George W. Bush, former Florida Governor Jeb Bush, Sen. Marco Rubio, Gov. Nikkie Haley, former California Governor Arnold Schwarzenegger, Sen. John McCain, 2012 GOP presidential candidate Mitt Romney, and even the Koch Brothers will not be attending the RNC Convention next week. But that is not seeming to weaken Trump.  It's Trump's party now, even reflected on the draft of the GOP Platform.
Staying at 100% because NeverTrumpers have failed every attempt they have tried this far proving their complete incompetence

Depends on how the Rules Committee goes regarding "unbinding" Trump delegates from being required to vote for Trump. There still seems to be some energy in the "Never Trump" crowd. This July 14 Washington Post article provides some insight: https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/post-politics/wp/2016/07/13/your-definitive-guide-to-the-rnc-rules-committee-meeting/ I'm raising my probability estimate Trump will win on first ballot. Trump's selection of Pence for VP might have helped Trump among conservatives.

Plan A won't work. Pence is acceptable to many republicans (Trump is smart, I'll give him that.) http://www.nbcnews.com/politics/2016-election/meet-woman-who-could-take-down-donald-trump-n608956
 "Her back-up plan is to convince 28 members of the Rules Committee — one-fourth of the 112 in attendance — to sign what's called a "minority report." If she achieves that threshold, she can be recognized on the floor of the full convention next week and give Trump opponents an opportunity to cast their vote for another candidate." Lack of viable candidate is a real problem. Also look at what happened to Grove when he ceasared boris johnson.

Never thought I'd ever ask this but...
Does anyone know of any links where I might be able to watch live commentary of the convention and the cordoned off protest area?
Pence is the insider to balance the ticket.  Never Trump crowd might have had some votes, but reports are, they do not have a candidate.

Slate: "After 10 or so hours of debate over occasionally interesting amendments, the RNC rules committee signed off for the night on Thursday by tanking the big one: the rule, proposed by Colorado delegate Kendal Unruh, that would unbind delegates from their first ballot obligations and allow them to vote their conscience. Never-Trumpers will continue to argue, perhaps forever, that they still have some snazzy new trick up their sleeve for snatching the nomination from Trump. But they don’t. It’s over." http://www.slate.com/blogs/the_slatest/2016/07/15/rnc_rules_committee_clears_path_for_trump_s_nomination.html

Un-binding of delegates wasn't likely ever a realistic idea. I watched an hour of the RNC Rules Committee meeting last night, it was clear only a small fringe of the committee actually took un-binding seriously. Trump people and the party chair are given credit for lobbying against it. They probably didn't need to bother.
The anti-Trump forces seem to have thrown in the towel. Staying away from 100% since everything this year has been wacky.
Near certainty now after rules votes
Pence scuppered that with his sincere Christian values. That and on going terror attacks which give force to trump's rhetoric
RNC Rules Committee offering no surprises for Trump.
trump voters who can't vote trump, won't vote hillary. They would likely vote another republican - assuming all goes according to Kendall Unruh's plan
GOP can change its own rules to unbind delegates.

Federal Court rules that Virginia (a "state") cannot require a delegate to vote for a specific candidate, but the political party, through its party/ convention rules, can.  
https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/volokh-conspiracy/wp/2016/07/11/federal-court-rules-virginia-cant-force-its-gop-convention-delegates-to-vote-for-trump/
Barring a pre-convention surprise, there is little reason to think Trump won't win on the first ballot.

I have no special information on this topic, but: Real betting markets currently have the odds of a [edit: non-]brokered convention at 92% to 93%. I trust betters in those markets more than I trust betters in this market because real-money markets are more liquid and have better incentives. I'm moving my probability up slightly to account for the very high probability posted here.

Va delegation is free to vote for whomever now.  Federal judge rules Trump delegate can oppose Trump, bars Virginia from enforcing its law to bind delegates. I suspect there will be other states, or maybe even a rules committee vote to allow all open, latter a wild card. I still think Trump could win an open convention. Definitely think he can win without a few delegations, Va included.

Federal Judge Rules for Anti-Trump GOP Delegate (-28)
http://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/judge-va-trump-delegate-unbound-voting-him-rnc-n607461 It is unclear exactly what the issue was in this particular case, but if it is interpreted to mean a dissolution of all state binding mechanisms for all delegates, chaos will reign and that's just too much uncertainty for me to retain a super-high forecast. Plunging down until the scope of this ruling is clarified.
Never trump has lost.  Updating appropriately.
I am forecasting based on the general news reports, PredictIt.com, 538.com, and GJP consensus.
This seems like a sideshow, but I'm inclined to downgrade slightly: http://www.wsj.com/articles/anti-donald-trump-forces-see-convention-coup-as-within-reach-1467839099
As Trump's favourability ratings with voters polled falls it strengthens the republican revolt and his chances get less

GOP Close To Dumping Trump As Coup Plotters Near Votes Needed To Cause Nomination Chaos 
http://www.politicususa.com/2016/07/06/gop-close-dumping-trump-coup-plotters-votes-nomination-chaos.html I wonder what happens to the coup plotters should the coup plot fail. They're certainly entitled to make their move, but should the coup fail, will the plotters be marched out the back of the convention center and summarily shot? It would seem difficult to unite the party with failed coup plotters moping around. Will there be a floor vote to strip the failed coup plotters of their credentials? Here's an interesting article that seeks to present some theoretical perspectives. Kind of, you know, ground the conflict on principles.
http://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2016/07/is-it-legitimate-to-deny-donald-trump-the-nomination/490115/ The only problem with this theoretical analysis is that the proffered "republican" approach presumes the primary voting systems have kept pace with this concept. They have not. Delegates were, for the most part, elected by voters based on a vague affiliation with their choice candidate. That is, even recognizing the role of delegates, voters had little, if any, information available to differentiate delegates based on principles, or values, or the like that might indicate how such delegates would employ their conscience. So it's quite disingenuous to promote a theoretical perspective when such a perspective was made impossible in practice. More precisely it should be called the "half-representationalism" approach.
Be very hard to diss candidate so favored by their voters. But if they change delegate rules.....

Repub delegates are being encouraged to "vote their conscience and country" instead of voting for Trump. However, many delegates could stick with Trump. Politico article: “Why Trump won’t get dumped in Cleveland” at http://www.politico.com/story/2016/07/donald-trump-cleveland-convention-225056 I'm slightly increasing my probability estimate Trump will win on first ballot.
If politics is teaching us anything this year (Boris Johnson not running being just the latest), nothing is 100% anymore, so dropping to 96%.

Down 5% to reflect difficulties Trump has had marshaling establishment support. But, given the lack of plausible alternatives, I see him winning the nomination on the first ballot.  No one else is currently challenging him for the nomination, and who else will the vote go to?
Due to the increasing rebellion against Trump, including by prominent Repub leaders, I'm lowering my estimate of a first-ballot win for Trump. It seems there could be a fight.
Back up 2%.The whole revolt idea was a long shot. Should make interesting theater instead of something boring.

Raising the probability of this - RNC clamping down on rebels
http://www.nytimes.com/2016/06/27/us/politics/donald-trump-and-rnc-see-common-foe-rogue-delegates.html?_r=0

All points to Trump being the nominee, and I think he will be, the question is if the opposition he is facing within his party will be but a scuffle at the start of the Convention or if it can create enough disruption as to prevent a first ballot Trump vote (some rogue delegates are suing, some are threatening to use a "conscientious objector" rule.
Upping forecast, but still not a sure thing, in my opinion.

There is an anti-Trump movement of sorts. Whether or not it'll make up the numbers on the convention floor is a very different question. Unless this gathers more momentum over the next few days I'll increase my forecast.
http://www.politico.com/story/2016/06/donald-trump-delegate-revolt-224634
The fact that the RNC now supports a Trump nomination means that he is likely to win on the first ballot.
Delegate Revolt, Republican Elite "Vote your conscience."
No change. Updating before resolution date & for participation purposes.

I am backing down here.  His party is in open rebellion.   And then there is this very interesting and surprisingly persuasive editorial on when the Donald would want to quit.  It makes too much sense for me to ignore.
http://gawker.com/how-is-donald-trump-going-to-quit-1782312998

Wow. I really thought this was a done deal. My reasoning was that party bosses would rather allow Trump to win that somehow tarnish the images of the RNCs policies. Moving the goalposts to get their way after the fact would cause even more desertion from the party because that would mean they couldn't be trusted to uphold the will of the people. However, there's a slight chance that some sort of shenanigans will occur. It won't help in the end, but unbinding delegates may spoil the first ballot.

chatter around delegates being unbound - by changing RNC rules. This might be a thing - not sure if they want to go against huge #'s of voters but recent CNN poll (tinkered?) showed that 48% of republicans now want to vote for someone else.
Trump will win on the first ballot. There is no evidence that any version of the #nevertrump movement has the power to stop him.

I am pretty sure Trump is going to win the nomination (what alternative do the Republicans have), but he is so disliked among the establishment and doing so poorly in the polls that it is possible the convention rules will be changed - unbinding delegates to Trump.  At that point, we have a civil war among Republicans.  What are the odds?  Who knows, but higher than 1 in 100 that I have predicted now.  Going to 1 in 20 (95%). To see how bad it's getting, read the following article on Paul Ryan - the chairman of the convention - saying it isn't his job to tell delegates what the rules should be.  Is this back room acceptance of a revolt, or is it politicians trying to not get dirty? https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/post-politics/wp/2016/06/19/paul-ryan-its-not-my-job-to-tell-delegates-what-to-do/?hpid=hp_hp-top-table-main_pp-ryandelegates-1013am%3Ahomepage%2Fstory https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-fix/wp/2016/06/19/the-brutal-numbers-behind-a-very-bad-month-for-donald-trump/?hpid=hp_hp-top-table-main_fix-trumpnumbers-923am%3Ahomepage%2Fstory
I guess there's no metaphysical certainty when it comes to what the GOP will or won't do, this unconventional season. I think it's well north of 99% but can no longer bring myself to round up.

There remains any manner of freakishly deranged lunacy when the GOP lights their big bonfire at the convention. However, Trump has a lock on the votes and delegates so he has to be the candidate. The longshot but only reality based alternative is a major front page news factionalization of the GOP at h convention leading a to essentially a new party. this would require party moderates to be activley engaged and planning which seems very unlikely, however a popular moderate could potentially lead a break off from the Trump block. Not sure who could or would pull it off. Someone new to the campaign cycle coming out of the trees with the "rich white guy credibility" and organizational energy to attract a first day block of support. Romney could try but won't because it's s failure guaranteed candidacy intening to build for the long road ahead. Maybe Susan Collins or someone really out there like Martha Stewart or Jon Voight. - it's all an extreme longshot but given the nutty for profit campaign trends it's a possibly to be noted.

A little doubt based on current polling. At least a contested (open) convention has excitement.  A demoralized one is most likely now.
Is there any VP candidate that could make this happy-exciting for them at this point?
Trump has enough pledged delegates to be nominated on the first ballot.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

Four in ten GOP insiders seek to deny Trump!
4-in-10 GOP insiders want to derail Trump at the convention
Politico - 2h ago
After a rocky start to his general-election campaign, a sizable number of GOP insiders want the party to change the rules to short-circuit Donald Trump's nomination at the July national convention.
http://goo.gl/Wd7B4v
Earlier low forecasts may have been ahead of the curve.  GOP may, now, start to give public consideration to the options still open for the convention.

---Delgates require the nominee to receive a "supermajority" rather than a "majority".
---Allow any candidate with 1 delegate to be entered into nomination (Cruz, Rubio, Kasich, Jeb!, Carson, plus more), preventing Trupm from obtaining a majority on the first vote.
GOP is behind the presumptive nominee so there is a pretty good chance to get the nomination on first ballot

I leave a 1% chance of back-room shennanigans and faithless delegates, which would be fun to watch, but devastating to our electoral process.  Speaker Ryan and Sen. McConnell know that their efforts to hold on to the majorities in Congress depend on the goodwill of Mr. Trump's voters come November.

People are settling into the idea of Trump like they settle into a hot bath. After the initial shock, the water isn't quite so hot.
Cruz and Kasich leave remaining delegates to Trump.

After Indiana, I ran millions of iterations of the remaining delegate possibilities with "winner take all" and proportional. Even without considering Cruz's drop out, Trump lands at the necessary number of delegates in approximately 70% (69.76%) of the cases. I think Cruz's withdrawal makes it far more likely than this suggests, but until we see how the subsequent support flows, this is where I am...

Looked at my forecast again. Trump is on such a role that he now should win Nebraska, which basically gives him 1237+. At that point Kasich should drop out and we have the contest most people were scared of, but at the same time secretly hoping for: Clinton V Trump.
With Cruz out of the race, Trump looks very likely to pick up enough committed delegates before the convention.
Indiana result seals the deal for Trump.

There have been a lot of twists to this election. As things stand now, Kasich can still have a contested convention if he sweeps a bunch of states and one of those states is California (which votes on the last day). If there is a contested convention, it might go to Kasich.
Oh dear. It's over I think. Trump wins.
It's DT's game to lose at this time.
DT will get 1237+ delegates, only possibility of preventing his candidacy is a change in rules. Which could quite possibly shatter the GOP, very very unlikely.
Absent rules change or sudden shift, this seems like a pretty sure thing.
I'd say 100%, but that is insane.  Let's stick with 99%.  Reason?  Cruz quit and Donald won Indiana.  Even if Cruz hadn't quit, Trump was maybe a dozen from 1237.  This contest is settled.

Trump wins Indiana.  Matching my forecast on the nomination winner question: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/225236

Recent wins have bolsters Trump's chances of a first ballot win. He is now likely to pick up the Pennsylvania delegates, and it is looking like a win in Indiana. That make even a modest win in California enough to put him over the top, and a strong win in California more likely.
Upgrading Trump based on early Indiana results and strong recent polling in California

No change to forecast:  A. Two supporting  points: 1) Rasmussen poll shows Donald Trump 41% vs Hillary Clinton @  39% http://m.rasmussenreports.com/public_content/politics/elections/election_2016/trump_41_clinton_39 2) Gallup poll shows Cruz's image plummets, Trump's among Republicans http://www.gallup.com/opinion/polling-matters/191264/cruz-image-plummets-trump-improves-among-republicans.aspx?g_source=Opinion&g_medium=lead&g_campaign=tiles Both polls confirm the public, when given the option to consider the above mentioned question, have a v different view than GOP powers that be who argue he can't beat HRC &, Senator Cruz is the best candidate.

The net is closing now on the STOP TRUMP folks.  Trump will probably win all of Indiana's 57 delegates today.  There are two other WTA states left (Montana - 27 delegates and S. Dakota - 29 delegates) where he will likely be favored.   The rest of the primaries are proportional.  If Trump wins Indiana today, he will need just 184 more delegates of the 397 remaining (46%).   Trump leads in polling in nearly all of these remaining states.  He's tied with Cruz in New Mexico.  Polls can sometimes be wrong, but the proportional system is such that they would have to be wildly wrong for Trump not to get 1237 delegates for the first ballot.
Moving up, as Trump does better.
Updating this to bring it in line with my forecast on Trump nomination.
Trump has a large lead in Indiana. Was Cruz' last stand
worried about the guy enough to go against the wishes of voters?
Yes. Trump will have enough delegates to get the nomination on the first ballot, when you consider unbound delegates who will probably vote for him.

The "never Trump" faction is determined to block his nomination. Trump is seen as destructive to the nation and party.
But Cruz is an even more divisive candidate who has been antagonistic to the Republican establishment, with whom he is now seeking to curry favor.
Kasich is positioned as the trustworthy and rational Republican but has little enthusiastic support. Some view his collaboration with Cruz as admitting that he is not seeking the Presidency, only to block Trump, leaving the nomination to Trump.
The path depends on which is seem as less destructive: (a) thwarting the will of voters, possibly losing Republican voters for years to come, in order to block a dangerous demagogue or (b) nominate Trump, accept that both parties will need to realign in coming years, knowing that Clinton is the likely ultimate victor, and hoping, in the event of a Trump presidency, that he is the pragmatic deal-maker that he claims to be.

According to the poll numbers, considering the fairly consistent polls over the past month on Trump's support, and all of the combinations of delegates from the remaining states, by my models, trump gets to 1,237  delegates only 52% of the time. No other candidate can get there, and if Trump doesn't make it to the magic number, there will likely be a brokered convention

Affirming prior. I think Cruz is on track to lose the states he has to win (IN and CA), and that DT will hit 1,237. I also think that a lot of mainstream Republicans have already written off their party's chances in 2016 and would rather see DT get the nomination and then be soundly defeated rather than go through a nasty floor fight only to see Ted Cruz be soundly defeated and still have DT making a ruckus form outside the tent.

Fear of popular revolt will keep GOP shenanigans in check.
Trump has the required number of delegates

Along with picking Donald Trump to win the nomination, I predict that it is extremely likely that he will win on the first ballot, before there is any chance to "correct" the voting of the Republican primary voters and caucus-goers.
Trump wins Indiana & California and gets to 1237
Trump wins IN and has good CA result. That's all she wrote!

Increasing my forecast significantly (50->80) due to the increased forecast for DT getting 1237+. He can get above those even without CA. So if he can pick up CA I think he will get 1237+ and therefore be the nominee on the first ballot.

Tweaking my forecast higher again.  90%.   As per 538, in Indiana, Trump has gone from a polls plus underdog to the leader. Indiana is a winner take all state, but that is also for the districts.  So, taking the 538 game quiz "can you get Trump to 1238", I just used expert opinion - with two exceptions.  I added 10 to Trump in Indiana (assuming the numbers are actually low and Nate didn't already bump them up this morning) and added 20 to California (it's a month out, and Cruz is starting to look desperate and to quote the Donald - like a loser).  Anyway, amazingly, the numbers came to exactly 1237. I think there are really two questions.  Was my bumping Indiana and California legitimate?  We will know more on Wednesday.  Assuming the first answer is no (I shouldn't monkey around with the 538 numbers), then does Donald get close enough to 1237 to make his not getting the extra votes cost the party more than just giving him the free delegates.  The alternative is a brawl at the convention, with no clear alternative (sorry Ted, no one likes you).  The party is becoming more and more concerned about down ballot votes, thus once again doesn't want a brawl. My wild guess at this point (and it is only a guess) is that Trump has a 30% chance of making 1237, he has a 50% of making over 1200 and easily picking up the delegates, and another 10% that he picks up the delegates, but there is lots of drama (whether he is under or over 1200).  10% that we go into a contested convention, and suffer the damage that will cause up and down ballot.

(Also posted here: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/222506, since it's relevant to both questions) I've decided to wait to reevaluate my forecast until Wednesday morning, but things are *not* looking that good for Sen. Cruz in Indiana[1], which is apparently a "weird" state[2]. At any rate, Trump is (about) a 2-to-1 favorite there at the moment[3][4]. Without a success in the winner-take-all Hoosier state, there's a good chance that Sen. Cruz won't be able to prevent Mr. Trump from getting to 1,237 delegates[5], lending some credence to Sam Wang's prediction of a final count of 1,284 delegates for Mr. Trump[6]. There's even some reason to think that the Cruz campaign is beginning to buckle[7]. Matter seem quite fluid indeed. -- [1] http://www.vox.com/2016/5/1/11549012/republican-polls-donald-trump-winning.

Trump now has 996 delegates. There are 371 at stake between now and the California primary (CA has 172). There are 131 delegates left at the 4 remaining primaries thereafter. That's a total of 502 delegates available to win before the Convention. If the actual trend in favor of Trump continues, and all is pointing in that direction, he is most likely to get at least 60% of those delegates. More than enough to claim the nomination by delegate count before the Convention.   On that note, the party seems to be thawing to the idea of Trump just as Trump's campaign seems to be "evolving."

If he can pull majority delegates in both Indiana and California, I have a hard time seeing him not getting the 30 or 40 uncommitted delegates he probably needs to win on the first nomination.  Indiana I think still favors Cruz at this point, although slightly, and California is no sure thing.

The Dougboy is hoping to be tapped for VP, as it will enable him to spend more time out of Jersey, for which most people there will envy him although they won't miss him.

I've just listened to a bit of Trump's latest speech in Indiana. Honestly, if he wins on the first ballot, then I'll have to revise my ideas about human nature. Mr. Trump's better than expected showing last night moved his mean expected delegate count from 1,191 to 1,200[a]. Quoth Nate Silver: "Based on provisional results,1 it looks as though Trump will sweep every pledged delegate in Maryland (as a result of winning every congressional district), Connecticut (as a result of winning every congressional district and getting more than 50 percent of the vote statewide), Pennsylvania (where statewide delegates are awarded winner-take-all) and Delaware (ditto), along with 11 of 19 delegates in Rhode Island (which is highly proportional). Combined with the New York results,2 that gives Trump 200 delegates since we issued the path-to-1,237 projections, five delegates ahead of his original targets"[b].  But what about variance? That's a hard question. I estimated the standard deviation among the expert predictions to be 45[c]. (An estimate was necessary since the description of the individual predictions was pretty sketchy.) But that number is now a month out-of-date, and we don't have (to the best of my knowledge) an updated survey from which to work (not a publicly available one anyway). I'd guestimate that the variance is narrowing since there are now far fewer delegates in play, but I don't have any confidence in that idea, so let's go with the status quo ante. Here's the probability distribution:   1,237+ = 0.21
1,200-1236 = 0.29
1187-1199 = 0.11 
1161-1186 = 0.19 
1137-1160 = 0.11
Less than 1137 = 0.09 Nothing's happened to change my mind since last time about the likely outcomes, which are 1,237+ –> 0.99 (If Mr. Trump goes over 1,236, he’s almost sure to win on the first ballot) 
1,200-1236 –> 0.85 (If Mr. Trump is over 1,200, he’s very likely to win on the first ballot) 
1187-1199 –> 0.68 (If Mr. Trump is within 50 delegates, he’s about a 2-to-1 favorite) 
1161-1186 –> 0.50 (If Mr. Trump is in the upper 1,100s his chances to securing enough delegates are about even-money) 
1137-1160 –> 0.25 (If Mr. Trump is this far away from 1,237 he’ll look weak and wounded, and delegates will be much less likely to to be wooed) So the probability that Mr. Trump will win on the first ballot is 0.99*0.21+0.85*0.29+0.68*0.11+0.50*0.19+0.25*0.11+0*0.09 = 0.65. Applying my 0.05 fudge factor[d], that gives a forecast of 0.70. I suppose that this passes the laugh test, but I'm highly unsure about it - especially given my cluelessness regarding variance here. GIGO, I suppose. Another approach would have been to look at the estimated delegate outcomes in each of the remaining states and then look at how far Mr. Trump has been from his expected outcomes in states that have already had primaries, using the latter to estimate variance. That's more work than I have time for, sadly. It's also problematic since in many of the earlier primaries Mr Trump had more than 1-and-a-half opponents, as he will in the remaining primaries. So I guess I'm sticking with my guns until I can think of something better to do. -- [a] http://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/election-2016/delegate-targets/republicans/
[b] http://fivethirtyeight.com/features/its-trumps-nomination-to-lose/
[c] http://fivethirtyeight.com/features/will-donald-trump-clinch-the-republican-nomination-before-the-convention/
[d] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/210642

Mr. Trump's surprisingly good showing in the New York primary requires some changes to my forecast. It's not that I didn't expect him to win; it's that I didn't expect him to win by such a significant margin. 90 out of 95 delegates? Reach for the smelling salts. Living oracle Nate Silver tells us that Trump's expected (mean) outcome is now 1,191 delegates[1]. Let's assume that the standard deviation is still 45 delegates. The result is the following probability distribution:  1,237+ = 0.16
1,200-1236 = 0.26
1187-1199 = 0.11
1161-1186 = 0.20
1137-1160 = 0.13
Less than 1137 = 0.14 Nothing's happened to change my mind since last time about the likely outcomes, which are 1,237+ –> 0.99 (If Mr. Trump goes over 1,236, he’s almost sure to win on the first ballot)
1,200-1236 –> 0.85 (If Mr. Trump is over 1,200, he’s very likely to win on the first ballot)
1187-1199 –> 0.68 (If Mr. Trump is within 50 delegates, he’s about a 2-to-1 favorite)
1161-1186 –> 0.50 (If Mr. Trump is in the upper 1,100s his chances to securing enough delegates are about even-money)
1137-1160 –> 0.25 (If Mr. Trump is this far away from 1,237 he’ll look weak and wounded, and delegates will be much less likely to to be wooed) So the new forecast is that there's a 0.58 [= (0.16*0.99)+(0.26*0.85)+(0.11*0.68)+(0.20*0.50)+(0.13*0.25)] chance that Mr. Trump will win the nomination on the first ballot. That's a pretty sharp uptick in his chances, and frankly I'm a little concerned that my model responded so decidedly because of a difference of about 20 delegates. The culprit might well be the half-assed way that I estimated variance; further study is in order. But I'll continue to update this business as primary results role in. -- [1] http://fivethirtyeight.com/live-blog/new-york-primary-presidential-election-2016/

I made a spreadsheet which calculates these probabilities based on some assumptions https://drive.google.com/open?id=0B9XMTgf2QMKfNUNISC1sc2hCcGs:
- The probability Trump picks up a PA unbound delegate (given he wins PA) - I used 55% since 61 out of 110 Pa delegates said they will vote for the state winner.
- The probability Trump picks up any other unbound delegate - I used 20%.
- The total number of unbound delegates - I used 150. The results show > 99% chance of getting at least 40 unbound delegates given those assumptions, and >75% chance of getting 50, with the probabilities dropping off steeply after that (eg only 33% chance of getting >= 56). Let's take a normal distribution w average estimate of 1187, ie 50% chance of getting to ~1187, which gives us 0.94 * 0.75 * 0.5 chance of getting to 1237 that way. So 20% + 35% for 55%.

The consensus forecast for this question has been dropping like a stone, falling about 21% since the first of April[0]. It's no longer possible to consider this an elaborate April Fool's joke. So perhaps it's time to revisit the question. Why the drop in the consensus forecast? One of the more interesting and oft-repeated new stories of the last week or two has been about the fact that Sen. Cruz's campaign seems to be very good at navigating through the unspeakably confusing maze that is the Republican primary system[1], while Mr. Trump's campaign is almost criminally incompetent at doing so. It's good print, and there's certainly something to this[2][3][4]. Maybe all of this explains why a lot of smart people have been running away from the idea that we'll have a single ballot in Cleveland.  But it's worth being on one's guard too. First, forecasters tend to be clever, detail-oriented people, and our preference would probably be to fight a cretinous bully like Mr. Trump with our wits, rather than our fists. And that's not too far from what Sen. Cruz himself is doing. Since it's likely what we (or at I) would play a similar hand this way, we (or, again, I) could be overly confident about how likely that strategy is to succeed. The world sometimes rewards us for overconfidence[5], but not here I think. And not for Mr. Trump either[6], though that's a story for another time. (None of the foregoing should be taken to mean I'm a fan of Sen. Cruz. I'm not.) Second, the story fits nicely into the seasoned-politician-vs-outsider narrative to which many in the media have given voice again and again. So not only are we likely to overestimate the efficacy Sen. Cruz's approach; so too we are likely to have second- and third-helpings of stories about Sen. Cruz's gnome-like minions researching the likes and dislikes of some random librarian/Republican delegate in Baton Rogue in order to convince her to go with the Senator rather than the (supposed[7]) billionaire: "Yes, Sen. Cruz shares your hatred for the recent adaptations of Jane Austen's novels, Ms. Gordon - may I call you Barbara? - and will have Ben H. Winters and Seth Grahame-Smith flayed alive in the Rose Garden." Okay, I made that one up, but you get the idea. But none of this means that Mr. Trump's got this locked up though. Far from it. The tricky bit is trying to quantify it all. What follows is a crude-but-not-crazy (I hope) attempt to do just that. The 9th level wizards over at FiveThirtyEight are currently offering a consensus projection that Mr. Trump will end up with 1,174 delegates after the last of the primaries is over[7]. That's great, but, dude, where's my variance? It's in another article. Sorta: "[T]here was a somewhat bimodal distribution in the total number of delegates our respondents expected Trump to reach. Three of us have Trump earning from 1,136 to 1,156, and three have him winning from 1,237 to 1,244. (The other two respondents have him in the 1200s but short of 1,237"[8]. Okay, that's better, but not perfect. The standard deviation is about 45 here. (I'm suppressing a bit of guess work that, as it turns out, doesn't have much impact on the outcome.) If so, Mr. Trump has a mere 8% chance of getting to 1,237 or higher. I repeat: 8%. That was a big surprise to me. And, on these assumptions, Mr. Trump has a only a 28% chance of getting over 1,200, the point at which some sources things he'd be close enough to get the nomination on the first ballot as the result of some pre-convention tinkering [9]. Other sources suggest that as long as he's within 50 delegates after California (38% likelihood), Mr. Trump will get the nomination on the first ballot[10]. The nice folks over at the University of Virginia's Center for Politics tell us, "Only if Trump finishes 100 or more delegates short does the contested convention become a more prominent possibility,"[11] and this little toy of a model I'm using predicts that there's a 79% that he will get at least 1,137.  On the basis of the above, I offer the following as a piecewise function taking us from the number of delegates that Mr. Trump eventually secures to the probability that he'll win on the first ballot. 1,237+ --> 0.99 (If Mr. Trump goes over 1,236, he's almost sure to win on the first ballot)
1,200-1236 --> 0.85 (If Mr. Trump is over 1,200, he's very likely to win on the first ballot)
1187-1199 --> 0.68 (If Mr. Trump is within 50 delegates, he's about a 2-to-1 favorite)
1161-1186 --> 0.50 (If Mr. Trump is in the upper 1,100s his chances to securing enough delegates are about even-money)
1137-1160 --> 0.25 (If Mr. Trump is this far away from 1,237 he'll look weak and wounded, and delegates will be much less likely to to be wooed)  As before, this is a crude approach, but if you think you can do better, then please tell me how because I'd love to learn a new trick or two. Anyway, from here it's pretty easy. Mr. Trump's chances of winning on the first ballot = (0.08*0.99)+(0.20*0.85)+(0.10*0.68)+(0.22*0.50)+(0.17*0.25)=0.47, with a little rounding up. That's remarkably close to the current consensus forecast! I guess I could have saved myself some time by going with it, but this was fun. I'm also adding 0.05 to counteract my biases I mentioned in the first few paragraphs.  Note: There's a lot of sloppiness above. Instead of a piecewise function, for instance, I should have fit a continuous curve and then integrated the function that describes it. But...you know...laziness. Plus, the results would not be that different, I think.  --- [0] https://www.gjopen.com/questions/123-will-the-republican-candidate-for-president-win-the-party-s-nomination-on-the-first-ballot-at-the-party-s-convention-in-july [1] http://www.politico.com/story/2016/04/trump-likely-to-win-west-virginia-but-lose-delegates-222036 [2] http://www.usnews.com/news/articles/2016-03-25/trump-holds-delegate-lead-but-cruz-maneuvers-to-outflank-him-at-convention [3] http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2016/apr/13/ted-cruz-eyes-double-agent-delegates-in-bid-to-sna/ [4] http://time.com/4287932/donald-trump-ted-cruz-delegates/ [5] http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v477/n7364/full/nature10384.html%3FWT.ec_id%3DNATURE-20110915 [6] http://fortune.com/2015/08/07/donald-trump-leadership-lessons/ [7] https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/wonk/wp/2016/02/29/the-myth-and-the-reality-of-donald-trumps-business-empire/ [8] http://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/election-2016/can-you-get-trump-to-1237/ [9] http://fortune.com/2016/02/26/delegate-math-republican-nomination/ [10] http://dailycaller.com/2016/04/14/can-trump-hit-1237-4-things-to-watch-for/ [11] http://www.centerforpolitics.org/crystalball/articles/assessing-trumps-path-to-1237/

We can place political processes on a spectrum of transparency or formality, or even better, participant knowledge. And we can gradate that spectrum from full black (covert, informal, limited knowledge) to full white (overt, formal, full knowledge [including understanding]). Here are two examples of political processes that are both close to the middle of the spectrum, but on opposite sides of the formal/informal divide.
1) The rules of procedure. Formal.
2) Who sets the agenda? Informal. (You'd be surprised at how many board of director meeting agendas are set unilaterally by the CEO or corporate secretary!)
http://www.politico.com/story/2016/04/republican-rules-clash-convention-222063 It's interesting to watch the RNC squirm when others seek to use "the rules." I am indifferent to the outcome, but give kudos to Ash who perceived that some rules were more amenable than others in terms of an "underlying political result." This is what I referred to earlier when I said that there is a democratic spirit even within the Republican party. The RNC Rules Committee chairman is seeking to keep the power with the delegates, whereas party leadership is seeking to centralize it within the presiding officer.

COMMENT:  Cruz & Kasich are banking on a contested convention, and Cruz, especially, is working hard to make it happen and to have his ducks lined up in a row when it does.  I haven't read anything on this yet, but I'm sure that the Cruz campaign is trying to stack the Rules Committee, as well.

If Trump arrives at convention with a majority, it is probably but not necessarily all over.  Of the roughly four ways a second ballot could be prevented, one could beat him even if he has a majority going in:  the Credentials Committee. If you stack that committee properly, it can disallow the credentials of the Trump diehards on some pretext or other.  This would require a majority on the floor to support such an action, but remember that not all delegates pledged to Grump on first are his supporters, and nobody is pledged to vote a particular way on Credentials, Platform, or Rules questions. So the party regulars who are designated for Trump could vote to disqualify their ostensible teammates.  You’d need to have some alternates available, but not a big problem.  The other three approaches require him not to have a majority coming in, as far as I can tell.  Next would be Platform Committee, which could if it felt like it write an actual Republican Party platform, leaving out all of his crazoid stuff and sternly denouncing anybody who holds more extreme positions.  If you handle it right, he’ll quit in a huff.  This is tricky, because nobody ever feels bound by the platform and he has recently acquired some advisors who actually know this.  However, if the draft contains language that is pretty clearly insulting to him, he might walk out.  This could perhaps work even if he comes in with a majority, if he either explicitly withdraws or you jigger the rules so his pledged delegates can’t vote for him; e.g., by not allowing his name to be placed before the body for some reason you could make up. Third is Rules Committee.  Rule 40 is an obvious target, even though the only nearly realistic beneficiary would be Kasich.  I haven’t looked at Republican convention rules in many years, but the odds are excellent there are some others that could be modified, repealed, or introduced that would lock him out on first.  Having control of Rules would also facilitate some of the other shenanigans herein contemplated.  That one and Method Four certainly require agreement on a new Anointed One. Method Four is a raw preconvention deal.  Cruz has been kissing up to Rubio, and together they right now have almost as many delegates as Hair Boy.  With Kasich and the Uncommittteds and a few others, they’d have more.  If it looks like he won’t have a majority, the poohbahs, if they can pick a winner, might be able to arrange a first-ballot win. Knitting together some combination of these might indeed lock him out.  All of this is the longest of shots, but very enjoyable to contemplate.  Still most likely as far as I can see is that he arrives with a majority and—perhaps after a couple of floor fights—wins on first ballot.   The Republican Party then goes the way of the buffalo: nearly extinct for a very long time, and gradually inching back.  Sorry this is so long.  Retired professors should either be kept busy or shot.

First time participant here but eager to learn.  My forecast was already going along the lines of the forecast made by @Pythagoras who ended at a 0.84 probability.  I merely expand on the analysis there to arrive at my own number. I have no reason to dispute the 0.68 of Trump securing all the necessary delegate votes to secure the nomination and instead look at the remaining 0.32. While Pythagoras divides the possible outcomes within the 0.32 to 2 outcomes I believe there are actually 3 outcomes because of the players involved and motivations. Those 3 outcomes within the 0.32 space are: Outcome 1: No candidate secures enough delegates to win the first ballot.
Outcome 2: A candidate uses any means to secure enough delegates to win the first ballot.
Outcome 3: The GOP leadership/convention rules committee comes up with a first ballot victor. Given the attention that conventions receive in the modern political age when convention location, timing, and agenda is all manipulated for maximum results and coverage, and especially in this tumultuous season, I believe the third outcome is a potential alternative independent of whatever efforts are taken by the candidates themselves in pursuit of their own interests.  The party may wish to minimize the coverage of a disputed nomination and at least attempt to converge behind a candidate at the last minute rather than give additional fuel to the party split narrative that will exist.  Part of this third scenario may be rallying behind Trump or Cruz through superdelegates and/or rule changes, or it might be a bold move to name a new candidate but do so with rule changes in the first ballot to again build that single party candidate narrative.  I could attempt to assign probabilities within those two scenarios but they ultimately end in the same third outcome of a first ballot win but motivated not by a candidate. Also in line with Pythagoras not being able to discern between those outcomes in the 0.32 space, I'll also give them equal weighting.  Since two of them result in a first ballot win, I arrive at 0.8933 (0.68 + (0.32 / 3 * 2))

Materially downgrading the probability that Trump wins a majority of delegates. Trump is currently at 751 (based on Frontloading HQ blog).  I think 238 delegates remain to be allocated from states with some degree of proportional allocation (I did not double-check my count, caveat lector!). I assume for simplicity that each candidate wins 1/3. This would take Trump to 830 (convenient!).  A balance of 407 bound delegates would be needed from WTA states. I believe there are 573 available (again, not double-checked). Loss of CA (172 delegates) would substantially reduce the probability Trump hits a majority. CA primary is a looong way away, so it is difficult to have confidence in any forecast. Qualitatively, Cruz is likely to perform well among religious conservatives and, if Kasich is still viable, he may also become a focal point for moderate Republicans who don't want Trump but don't want Cruz either. I will assume for now that CA is a three-way toss-up.  Conditional on Trump winning CA, he still must win multiple key states. NJ and PA (122 combined) seem probable for Trump, although again it is very early. It is plausible that, if Kasich remains viable, he would have a similar impact as described above. I am purely guessing that Trump will appeal to the anti-establishment types in MT (27) and WV (34). That total would still be short by 52 delegates. It seems plausible that Trump might win the additional 1-3 states required to pass the hurdle, but it does not seem like a given. Bottom line is that the probability of Trump hitting a majority seems much more sensitive to key events (namely California and whether or not Kasich drops out) than at the time of my original forecast. I will say roughly 5% probability of Trump securing a delegate majority, conditional on losing CA (67% probability) and roughly 50% probability conditional on winning CA (33%). That comes out to about 20%. I upgrade to 25% because Trump remains the front-runner and people seem to have an inexplicable preference for front-runners.

http://www.politico.com/story/2016/03/republican-convention-rules-trump-cruz-221355 "All four early appointees to the rules committee for this year’s Republican National Convention told POLITICO they’re prepared to weaken or scrap a rule that could limit the convention’s alternatives to Donald Trump. The four took issue with a rule. . .  requiring a candidate to win a majority of delegates in eight states to be eligible for the party’s nomination — a threshold only Trump has exceeded so far. If preserved, the rule could block John Kasich or Ted Cruz from competing with Trump at the convention. . .  "If the committee scraps the requirement entirely, it could open the door to multiple candidates, possibly even some who never entered the primaries, competing for the party’s nomination at a brokered convention. And even a lower threshold would make it easier for Trump’s rivals to challenge him.
. . . 
"If Trump doesn’t effectively clinch the Republican nomination by the June 7 end of the primary season, the rules committee is destined to be the epicenter of political wrangling and horse-trading leading up to what would be the first contested convention since 1976. " . . . Eventually, the committee will include a man and a woman from every state and U.S. territory — a total of 112 people. But interviews with the four members, as well as two veteran Republicans who hope to join the panel, provide an early window into the factors that could drive the committee’s decision-making. Though the panel is imbued with virtually unchecked power to draft rules that tip the nomination away from Trump — or into his grasp — most of the panelists and prospective members indicated their actions would be guided by a different principle: caution. “We don't want to give the impression that we are leaning one way or the other in support or trying to hold somebody else back,” . . .“Fundamentally, I hope we keep the way we’re doing it,” said Ross Little Jr., a rules committee member from Louisiana. “I’m not looking for a gigantic change.”
. . .
"Members of the rules panel are aware that any changes to the process that lower barriers for Trump’s competitors — even adjustments to the eight-state rule — could be seen as an affront to the front-runner.“Any proposed change will be viewed as to which candidates would be helped and which candidates would be hurt. It’s a classic example of changing the rules in the middle of the game,” “It would be widely and correctly viewed as that outrageous power grab.”
. . . 
"Trump has already groused about Cruz’s efforts to elect his supporters as delegates to the national convention, a dynamic that could create challenges for Trump on the rules committee, as well as on the floor of the convention, if he’s unable to secure the nomination beforehand. . . . any sudden rules changes could create a public relations headache for the committee
. . . 
"Veteran national Republican committeeman Curly Haugland is the lone exception to the light-touch approach. He was on the rules committee in 2012 and said he intends to pursue a slot this year as well. Haugland has for years insisted that delegates to the national convention cannot be restricted from voting their conscience. Currently, delegates are bound to vote on a first ballot according to the results of the contest in their state. But if no nominee is selected, most are free to shift their support on later ballots. Haugland, however, argues that delegates are elected by fellow Republicans to exercise judgment on the convention floor, and should be free to vote as they please even on the first ballot. He said he intends to persuade the rules committee — as well as the convention delegates writ large — to enact changes that would allow delegates to vote for any candidate who has earned a delegate in the 2016 voting.
. . . 
" . . . Haugland is unlikely to find much help in his quest. Freeing delegates would invalidate the months-long election season that all three campaigns have battled relentlessly to win. “I would not favor changing the rules regarding binding” delegates to follow their state’s voters on the first ballot, said [committee member] Wheeler. “That is a core concept of how we arrive at our delegates and how we translate the votes of the people to the nominee.”
. . .
“Right now, I don’t want the scandal of a [sweeping] change in the rules,” [committee member] Blackwell said. “Whomever we nominate will be more likely to win if we haven’t had a significant element in the party claiming that the rules have been changed to favor one candidate or oppose one candidate.”
~~~~~~~

I learned a new word today, and it's "preconvention"[a]. Until now, I had assumed that *only* the following states of nature were salient: State 1: Some candidate wins at least 1,237 of the delegates by the last primary, and the nomination goes, in the first ballot, to that candidate.
State 2: No candidate wins at least 1,237 of the delegates after the last primary, and no candidate wins the nomination in the first ballot at the convention. Not so! There is a period of about 6 weeks between the last primary (June 7) and the convention (July 18) during which candidates can lobby delegates. So, to take one example, Mr. Trump might fall short of 1,237 delegates in early June but still secure enough delegates before July 18 in order to be nominated on the first ballot at the convention in Cleveland. Put another way, there are really 3, not 2, salient states of nature: State 1: Some candidate wins at least 1,237 of the delegates by the last primary, and the nomination goes, on the first ballot, to that candidate.
State 2: No candidate wins at least 1,237 of the delegates after the last primary, and no candidate wins the nomination on the first ballot.
State 3: No candidate wins at least 1,237 of the delegates after the last primary, but some candidate secures enough delegates - by hook or by crook - before the convention to be nominated on the first ballot. As before, I assign a probability of 0.68 to State 1, with Mr. Trump (ca. 0.98) being far more likely than Senator Cruz (ca. 0.02) to be the victor, should we find ourselves in this state. And I am increasingly convinced that this process will go down to the wire though[b]. (This fact has relevance for the GJ question about when Senator Cruz will drop out: He probably won't!)  That leaves a probability space of 0.32 for the disjunction of States 2 and 3. I honestly have no idea how to divide up this probability space, so I'm going to fall back on the principle of insufficient reason and just cut the damn thing in half. I think we'll have a better idea soon, but it's just too early to make anything more accurate than a stab in the dark. By the way, if I were a member of the #nevertrump Republican elite, I'd be working very hard to make sure that the people who are selected as delegates[c] are not the sort who are easily swayed by the prospect of gold-plated steaks[d] or whatever you kids are into these days. On a side note, if Mr. Trump cannot secure the nomination during the pre-convention stage (should it come to that), I think he enters the convention considerably weakened. His schtick is that he's a "master negotiator"[e]. But if he gets about 1,100 delegates and still can't seal the deal during the six-week pre-convention, then the bloom's off the rose.  Anyway, I now estimate the current probability that a candidate will be successfully nominated on the first ballot to be 0.84 (=0.68+(0.32/2)). -- [a] http://www.bloombergview.com/articles/2016-03-11/republicans-new-target-the-pre-convention [b] http://fivethirtyeight.com/features/the-most-important-states-on-trumps-path-to-1237-delegates/ [c] https://www.gop.com/the-official-guide-to-the-2016-republican-nominating-process/ [d] https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=897&dat=19491201&id=PtEKAAAAIBAJ&sjid=FFADAAAAIBAJ&pg=3186,1095855&hl=en [e] http://www.businessinsider.com/donald-trump-negotiation-money-golf-2015-10

Trump is presently at 96% of the delegate target established by 538 (http://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/election-2016/delegate-targets/). 
Using 538's tracker, he needs 40+ delegates in the following states:
- California (81/172). Winner-take-all, mostly at the congressional district level. There haven't been any polls since December; at that point the totals were 25% Cruz, 23% Trump and 1% Kasich. That would put Trump close to where he needs to be, though dropouts since (Rubio/Carson/Paul had combined for 28%) probably move more support to Cruz than Trump in my view. 
- Arizona (58/58). Winner-take-all. Last poll was in November and had it a three-way race between Trump, Carson and Rubio; I like Trump's chances. 
- New York (58/95) Proportional, mostly at a congressional district level, unless someone gets over 50%. Trump is at 45% in a recent poll, Kasich 18% and Kruz 11%. Even assuming Rubio's support largely goes to Kasich, there's a chance Trump tops 50% and takes everything.  
- Indiana (51/57). Winner-take-all, mostly at the congressional district level. No recent polling, but Trump won Michigan, Illinois and Kentucky. Kasich won Ohio to the East and was competitive in Michigan. Cruz was competitive in every bordering state other than Ohio. I think Trump takes most of the state, but 51 delegates is iffy. 
- New Jersey (51/51). Winner-take-all. In a February poll, Trump was at 33.3%, Rubio/Carson combined for 25.4%, with Cruz at 7.7% and Kasich at 4.3%. Nearly a lock for Trump, unless the dropout delegates universally go to his rivals. 
- Pennsylvania (40/71) 17 delegates are winner-take-all, the rest go in a "loophole" primary. The last RCP average had Trump at 29%, Rubio at 19%, Cruz at 17% and Kasich at 13%. Trumps chances here would seem to be good. 
Going through all that, I'm not sure my gut feel - which has Trump really close but not a lock to meet his delegate target changes much. It's close to 50/50 whether he crosses that magic threshold in my view; I'm tabbing him slightly under.

NO CHANGE. I've been at 100% since the day this IFP was published (https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/99433) and I have no intention of backing away from that anytime soon. A contested convention is a journalist's dream, so reading about the possibility of it happening is essentially the "catnip" of whoever is writing it. In the thread I linked to above, I showed that there really haven't been any "contested" conventions that we can look to when trying to form a base-rate for forecasting on this IFP, but I did come across an article that might help those who are being persuaded by the siren song of the illusion that is the contested convention. NOTE: I've gone ahead and included the whole article. For those of you who read my forecasts, I usually edit out the extraneous parts, but I think that the whole article helps to paint the picture that, a contested convention is NOT in the interest of the GOP (did you see the protests in Chicago tonight?!) and that there are ways for a candidate to get to 1237 (before) the convention, even after all the states have cast ballots in primaries.
~ Mar 11: "Republicans' New Target: The 'Pre-Convention'" --> http://www.bloombergview.com/articles/2016-03-11/republicans-new-target-the-pre-convention The Republican delegate tangle has people talking excitedly about a contested national convention this summer. Not so fast. Even if no candidate wins the necessary 1,237 delegates by the end of primaries and caucuses on June 7, the six weeks that follow provide another opportunity to settle the matter before the party gathers in Cleveland on July 18. I’ll call this period the “pre-convention.” Republicans can't have an undecided convention without first passing through a contested pre-convention period. With all the delegates chosen but no candidate having a secure majority, the action will shift from the week-to-week slog from one state primary to the next in search of voters to a collective decision to be made by the delegates: 2,472 party actors, most of them obscure but a handful well known, most of them loyal to the candidate they are supporting but many of them with other interests and preferences. If no one has the nomination locked up in June, everyone involved -- candidates, delegates and other party actors -- will feel intense pressure to get this done before the convention. The purpose of national conventions today is advertising for the party and its candidate, and that opportunity would be forfeited if the convention was convened without a nominee. The worst case would be day after day of deadlock under the full gaze of the national media with controversies heating up and plenty of chances for those 2,472 delegates (and the hundreds of other Republicans who will be in attendance) to make the party and whomever they eventually settle on look bad. So the campaigns will scramble to win the allegiance of delegates, both those who are not tethered to a particular candidate and those who are, since bound delegates might become available if the convention decides to let them vote however they want.   Delegates who are unbound and uncommitted won’t necessarily wait until Cleveland to commit. As some of them declare for a candidate (and are added to the tallies news organizations keep), the delegate counts will change as the convention approaches. A candidate could go over the top during those six weeks. The lead could change. What happens during the pre-convention will depend partly on how close the front-runner is to 1,237 delegates, and on how big the gap is between him and the second-highest vote-getter.  Party actors, including delegates, may care which candidate has won the final contests, including some in big states like California, as well as what the national polls are saying. Even if they haven't publicly committed to a candidate, some party leaders may contact delegates to discuss a course of action, and even push some contenders to step aside in favor of someone who has a chance to wrap up the nomination early. Most Republican delegates will have been chosen as “bound,” meaning they would be required to vote for a certain candidate on at least the first ballot in Cleveland. A small number will be chosen as “uncommitted,” meaning they could choose to support any candidate before the convention, or change allegiance from one to another. Another batch of delegates -- anywhere from a few dozen to several hundred -- will have been selected to be delegates for a candidate who has withdrawn. Depending on their state party rules, some will be bound to support their candidate anyway, at least on the first ballot. Others will be free to choose. Even some of those who are pledged to vote for a candidate who is still running could conceivably be in play. Unlike the Democrats, the Republicans in many states separate the selection of the individual delegates from the allocation of how they are supposed to vote on the first ballot for a given candidate. This means many delegates could be bound to vote for a candidate despite not actually supporting him. For example, Donald Trump won the Virginia primary on March 1 and was allocated 17 of Virginia’s 49 delegates. Separately, Virginia Republicans are holding a series of party conventions in April and May in each of the state's congressional districts to select the actual delegates. Seventeen of those delegates will be assigned to Trump, and under the tentative rules they will have to vote for Trump on the first ballot in Cleveland. But there’s nothing in the rules to guarantee Trump is the actual preference of those 17 people. This means that even a candidate who has captured 1,237 delegates by June 7 might not be truly safe. It's unclear if Republicans would be willing to thwart the will of their voters by upending a chosen winner, but if the delegates want to, nothing can stop them. This too is a fight that could start during the pre-convention. Unfortunately, we have little historical precedent for how this jockeying works in practice. It’s possible that well-organized campaigns will have been able to secure their choices for delegates and that poorly organized campaigns will have had less success. By the pre-convention period, one or more candidates might have a real advantage in the share of their delegates who are truly loyal. So not only are the rules confusing and subject to interpretation. They're also subject to change. The tentative rules for the convention bind all delegates to vote the way they were allocated on the first ballot, but the convention can change those rules. So we may be in for a convention floor fight about whether to “free” the delegates to vote how they choose. If so, the first rounds of that fight and any other rules fight will take place in the pre-convention period, when the convention Rules Committee is chosen and begins its deliberations. Another possibility: fights in the convention credentials committee about any disputes over who the properly elected delegates might be. In the old days of brokered conventions, party bosses chose delegates who would do as they were instructed. Today’s delegates have far more leeway to do what they want. So if, for example, Marco Rubio drops out after losing Florida on Tuesday and endorses Cruz, the delegates he has won so far wouldn’t necessarily have to listen to him or anyone else. And efforts to win commitments from those delegates would hardly wait until the convention.   However uncharted the period is between the end of the primaries and the beginning of the convention, if no one reaches 1,237 by June 7 then party actors will press hard to get everything resolved before everyone arrives in Cleveland. If they’re successful, the convention won’t appear to have been contested after all. If not? There's a good chance of absolute chaos, with everyone watching.

Updating from my second prediction after an interesting Saturday.  Rubio had a terrible night and it is now obvious that he has absolutely no path to 1237 delegates. Cruz had a fantastic night. Trump had a bad night.

Still, Trump came away from today still on track to make the nomination. 538 have his target total at this point in the race as 366 delegates. So there is a 69% chance Trump doesn't make the 1237. 
Previously I was giving Trump a generous probability (.75) of turning a Super Tuesday win into a majority part of this was based on the assumption that momentum was on his side. He too would need to win Florida, which is basically no chance with Rubio in the race, and with the FL primary only a a bit over a week away, I don't think there's really any chance that Rubio drops out before it. I'll be generous and give Cruz a 1% chance of getting to majority. So that's a 68% chance that nobody has a delegate majority going into the convention. I will assume that no clear majority in bound delegates means no decisive first vote, giving only 32% chance of a first ballot nomination.

I am not sure that this question is different from whether any candidate will have a majority of delegates prior to the convention. The probability that a candidate other than Trump wins a majority of delegates seems vanishingly small. Trump appears to be on track to win a majority of delegates, but the Republican establishment seems to have shifted strategy towards conceding Trump a plurality if they are able to prevent a majority. Trump appears to be on track to win a considerable share of the ~750 delegates between today and March 15. The key question is whether the gap to the majority could be closed based solely on "hitting the board" in future primaries that allocate proportionally. In that case, it is difficult for me to see how an establishment-led push against Trump could deny him a majority. It appears that the upcoming contests most likely to go against Trump (which is not to say that they are likely to do so) are Ohio (66, winner take all), North Carolina (72, proportional) and Florida (99, winner take all). I will attempt to simplify by asserting: (a) if Trump is beaten in at least two of these states, the establishment will double down on a strategy to deny Trump a majority, and I will assume for now that it can succeed; (b) otherwise, Trump is highly likely to be able to obtain a majority. Based on 538's current forecast about the probability of a Trump win in these states (38%, 45% and 69% respectively) it looks like the probability that at least two go against Trump is ~50%. I bump the general probability that he obtains a majority to 60% because, well, he's winning so far, and my simplifications generally skew against him winning a majority.

Updating from my first prediction (http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/154170) after Super Tuesday results. The conditional I had, of Trump emerging from Super Tuesday with a delegate lead, has occurred. But I think my odds (80%) for Trump turning that lead into a majority were too high. I also think that the outcome of Super Tuesday - Cruz winning many more delegates than Rubio, putting Cruz in 2nd place, but with Cruz's strong states mostly already past and Rubio's yet to come - meaning it will be hard for either of them to gain a majority. The most likely outcome now is, in decending order: 
- a Trump majority (I think this is >50% likely)
- a Trump plurality (and thus a contested convention)
- Rubio somehow turns it around and scrapes a majority (seems highly unlikely now)
- Cruz somehow obtains a majority (basically zero chance) This outcome is likely to affect the Republican strategy in a way that makes a contested convention significantly more likely. Because their last remaining likely strategy now is to just try and stop Trump from getting to 1267 delegates.
http://www.slate.com/articles/news_and_politics/politics/2016/03/rubio_cruz_and_kasich_will_all_stay_in_the_gop_race_why.html So I think that they will be trying to make it harder for Trump to run away with things than if it were in a head to head (which would have been all or nothing but still held some chance of one of the others getting to a majority). The NYT has sketched out the two opposing scenarios - the one that leads to Trump winning a majority, and one that denies him the majority (but nobody else gets one either). http://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2016/02/27/upshot/republican-delegate-calculator-how-trump-can-win.html The probability of Trump getting a majority is the key calculation then. If I fiddle with the calculator here, http://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2016/03/02/us/super-tuesday-results-delegates.html just putting Trump at 37% support, which is the weighted average calculated by FiveThirtyEight at the moment, would see him easily win a majority. And his national poll numbers have been trending up. This gives me more confidence in my 80% chance of a majority estimate, and in fact that almost seems too low given the state of things (no clear second place after Super Tuesday - so it will not turn into a one-on-one race soon). However I think I will give Trump only a 75% chance of obtaining a majority because I think the strategies of all the other candidates will now shift to simply attempting to prevent him from getting to 1267. And I think I give only a 1% chance of either Cruz or Rubio winning a majority (I think the chance is nearly zero if one of them doesn't drop out very soon, and I put that chance at ~1%). So that's a 76% chance of someone getting a majority before the convention.

The fact that Cruz was able to win several states, and Rubio one, indicates to me that Trump might not yet have the decisive support of the party needed to secure the nomination before the convention. However, the remaining states appear to be less than favorable for Cruz, while Rubio is currently predicted to lose his home state of Florida, which is winner take all. If Rubio loses Florida to Trump it seems unlikely that Trump would not be able to secure a majority of the delegates. In addition, FiveThirtyEight currently has Trump at 112% of his target delegates to win the nomination, with Cruz at 58% and Rubio at 48%. I'm lowering my forecast from 85% to 80% as a result of the continued ambiguity, but will reassess after the 8th and 15th.

Before Super Tuesday, I was at 85%. The GOP launched coordinated attacks on Trump. Rubio, Cruz, Ryan, Fox News, and other media. The ideal outcome for the GOP establishment would have had Rubio winning Virginia, and doing better overall. The GOP does not want Cruz to be the alternative. Further, Cruz does not have many strong-holds where he will be a big favorite to win states, where as Rubio's future states are stronger. If the GOP wants to deny Trump the nomination, its best strategy may be to keep three or more candidates in the race, and have a brokered nomination. As long as Cruz and Rubio are in the race, it is unlikely that any one candidate will get close to 50% of the votes or delegates. If Kasich stays in through March 15 (he will), he is a favorite to win all 66 delegates in the Winner-take all primary.  In the future, Rubio and Kasich are natural allies. They are the least radical-sounding of all candidates. It's feasible in July, there is no clear winner, and a Rubio/Kasich alliance (or even Rubio with Kasich's support if Kasich drops out after the Ohio primary) that the GOP can have Rubio as its establishment candidate. It's not very likely, but the possibility is enough to lower my estimate from 85 to 72%.

I liked all the top comments on this one ( @einsteinjs & others).  My view here is that if it were possible to force a brokered convention, the establishment would do it (chaos for the party, or no).  I simply do not believe it is possible for them to stop Trump's nomination at this point.   First, some #'s to frame it up:  
To win on 1st ballot, DT needs 1,237 of 2,472 (50% + 1)
To date, The Donald, has 82 out of 133 delegates awarded thus far (62%). 
Tonight, we get 624 more of which he only "needs" 246 to stay on track.  However he is ahead in every state but TX, and I'd be floored if he does not get more. See here:
http://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2016/president/march1GOP.html
 And here:
https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-fix/wp/2016/02/25/donald-trump-needs-to-win-only-39-percent-of-super-tuesday-delegates-to-stay-on-pace-to-be-the-gop-nominee/ There are then several more proportional contests in next 2 wks w/ total of 356 add'l delegates.  The Donald is similarly doing well in many of these states, and there is no reason to think he will not get huge slugs of these delegates.   624 + 326 = 950.  I think there are probably reasonable arguments that depending on how the chips fall, Trump may come away with anywhere between 30 and 70% of these delegates (depends on if Cruz can lock up TX, etc).  Regardless, he is VERY likely to lead any of the other candidates in delegates, although I'd grant that whether he remains "on track" to avoid a contested convention w/ >50% of the delegates or not is an open question.   Depending on how those states fall, he will come into March 15th with ~40-60% of the delegates that have been awarded (and ~1/2 of the R delegates will have been awarded by that point).  Starting on March 15th, the states change from being largely proportional to being predominantly "winner take all," and 1,266 delegates remain to be awarded.  Other candidates running have certain advantages in individual states (Kasich in Ohio and Rubio in FL), but Trump is leading in virtually all of these late states (incl in FL & OH actually - see realclearpolitics link above).   The key question here is will the non-trump vote be able to consolidate and win >50% of these late states, or not.  Winning just a few (OH, FL, etc) is not nearly good enough, they need to deny him more than 1/2 of the late states or he will hit his number and be able to win on the 1st vote at convention.  To do that, you can be sure R establishment will apply immense pressure to get candidates who cannot win to drop out (Carson ASAP, and Kasich/Rubio after they contest OH/FL respectively (presumably keeping the one that wins.  If they both win & want to stay in, that might be worse case scenario).  Cruz may keep puttering along.  I think his remaining voters would probably break away from Trump more than for them, but It's not really in Cruz's personality to drop out, and it is clear he does not care if the establishment hates him, so there is nothing to hang over his head.  In 2 weeks, we'll probably have experienced 2 more weeks like the last one (absolutely withering attacks on Trump from all quarters.  Split, proportional votes in most states, most candidates with exception of maybe Carson staying in the race).  At that point, will Rubio, Kasich, or Cruz alone have higher support than Trump in a majority of the remaining states??  Can Trump's negatives be driven up high enough to put a dent in his support and/or can the establishment successfully rally nearly EVERY non-Trump primary voter around just one other person?    If they could assemble that coalition, will that person be able to run the tables in the late states and thus provide the R's with a non-Trump uncontested convention?   I do not think it is at all likely Trump can be stopped, but I'm not positive.  In my view, he has too many voters committed to him, and it is too late in the game to change those voters minds.  I'd put it at 90-10 in terms of outcomes.  If he were stopped, it's probably because something HUGE comes out that causes voters to re-evaluate.  If they do, it's probably real bad, and he probably stops winning states.  If that happens, can someone else coalesce support, or does vote splinter between Cruz-Rubio-Kasich?  I don't know, but I'd say at least 50-50 that it coalesces around one.     Thus overall, I'll put it at 95-5 on this (90 Trump, 5 someone else, 5 contested), vs. 80-20 consensus.  We'll see after Super Tuesday and maybe a few more of these proportional voting dates whether the negative assault from party R's seems to have any impact on his support.

Some ideas: Base rates: Brokered conventions in 1952 (Dem) and 1948 (Rep), if we assume one every 50 years that's one per 12.5 elections, or 8% chance. Assume every 100 years gives 4% chance. However the rules around primaries were changed in the 70s, may help reduce the chance of there not being a clear winner. For a non-conclusive vote there would have to be a couple of events - first, no candidate with a clear majority before the convention, and second, no clear winner emerging from the behind-the-scenes horse trading before the first vote.  Back in December Nate Silver guesstimated that there was a 20% chance of a brokered convention. 
https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/republican-brokered-convention-donald-trump/ That seems too high to me, especially now that there is a real chance trump simply runs away with the nomination and is actually able to secure > 50% of delegates outright.' If Trump doesn't secure 50% of delegates before the convention, I would give an almost 100% chance that the first vote does not select a clear winner. So really this question is about: can Trump secure > 50% of delegates? This is looking increasingly likely. I give him 95% odds of emerging from Super Tuesday with the most delegates (though likely not a majority of those awarded thus far). That can create a bandwagon effect, leading to even better results subsequent. However the field may also winnow after Super Tuesday - if it turned into a head-to-head race between Trump and Rubio I'd expect things to get considerably harder for him. I think I give trump a ~85%  chance of pulling ahead to a clear majority after a super tuesday lead, and a 5% chance someone else gets there. And I think I give Rubio only a ~50% chance of closing the gap and getting to a delegate majority in the case he comes out ahead after super tuesday (which I put at 4% chance), and no chance anyone else does. And though I think it unlikely Cruz can get to a delegate lead at Super Tuesday (1%) I give him a 10% chance of turning that into a majority, and a 5% chance someone else does. So that gives us a .15*.95 + .5*.04+.85*.01 =17.1% probability of nobody with a delegate majority by the convention. And I'll give a 98% weight to the first vote being inconclusive should that happen, so we have ~17% chance. The question is for the converse, so 83%. My biggest doubt is that 85% chance of Trump turning a Super Tuesday delegate lead into an absolute delegate majority number. Though I don't know if it's too high or too low. Also my heavy discounting of the possibility of the first vote deciding it, where there is no clear majority, may also be an oversight. This would be a good direction for further research (eg has it happened before, etc)
