My rationale is the following. First, the outside view: the last Republican convention with more than one ballot was in 1948. The last Republican convention that was very close to be brokered was in 1976. So odds are largely against a brokered convention.  This in means that in modern elections (with primaries or caucauses used in all states) the voters tend to decide on the victory  (defined as 50% +1  of the delegates) of a single candidate during the primaries being the convention most of the times a mere pro-forma. 

The 2016 Republican race seems no exception, in  spite of the many candidates running.  Trump is ahead, collecting most of the delegates so far, and in position to collect much more in both Blue and Red states. Behind there is a diminishing array of candidates with non-Trump delegates concentrating on only Cruz or Rubio. In the next few weeks, Carson and Kasich may fall. Eventually it is very likely that either Cruz or Rubio may give-up, concentrating the race in only Trump and an anti-Trump candidate.  The only difference in the 2016 election lies on the fact that none of the race leaders is really a favourite of the party machine.  So, my forecast is 90% yes.  Conditions to change my forecast: - unexpected resiliency on the part of one or more of the non-Trump candidates: if both Cruz,  Rubio or Kasich can get an impressive number of delegates it may put them in a position to bargain. This is especially true since Rubio, Cruz and Kasich are from big states (Florida, Texas and Ohio) where they are likely to win. Florida, Texas and Ohio are thus states to watch in order to tune this forecast.

There is very good reason to think that the Republican candidate for president will get the party's nomination on the first ballot. That reason is that this has happened at every Republican convention in every election cycle for the last 68 years. The last brokered Republican convention was in 1948[1]. So the _outside view_ has to be that the probability that the Republican candidate for president will not get the party's nomination on the first ballot is close to zero.  Well, not so fast. Here's a point that was made by Nate Silver some time ago[4]. Sure, there hasn't been a brokered Republican convention in almost 7 decades, but conventions don't happen very often, so the sample size of data is pretty small. Furthermore, there have been a number of near misses. Republicans had a close call in 1976 when the then sitting president Gerald Ford lacked enough delegates to secure the nomination before the convention but somehow managed to gain enough support at the last moment to edge out challenger Ronald Reagan[2]. So if we start the clock at 1948, we'd have a 1/17 probability (round up to 6%) of a brokered convention as a baseline.  And there are some positive reasons for thinking it might happen this year. At the moment, there simply isn't a clear frontrunner for the Republican nomination. '“It’s hard for me to see why a round of brokering in Cleveland isn’t the most likely outcome,” says Daniel Heninger, deputy editor of the Wall Street Journal’s editorial page. “None of these candidates looks likely to pull away and capture the majority of primary delegates before the party’s nominating convention in Cleveland next July.”'[3] Fair enough, but there's this kind of talk during almost every election cycle on one side or the other[4]. A slightly more nuanced take is this: Trump appears to hover around 25%-35% in the primary polls. There's some evidence that his ceiling is 1/3 of the Republican primary voters[5]. If (and it's a big "if") that's true, and if (here's another big "if") candidates like Cruz, Rubio, Bush, and Kasich manage to split the anti-Trump vote[6], then there's a clear path to a failure to get a Republican nominee after a first round of voting at the convention.  All that said, media consumers like me need to be careful. Many journalists would love to be able to cover a brokered convention[7] (and I would too if I were a journalist), so they're likely to suffer from the positive valence effect[8]. I need to be careful so that I don't internalize this sort of bias. With all of this in mind I'd say that the current likelihood that the Republican candidate for president not win the party's nomination on the first ballot is about twice the baseline, rounding down 1 point in the hopes of avoiding the positive valence effect: 11%. Of course, this number will need to be updated often as the convention gets nearer. [1] http://www.cnn.com/2015/12/11/politics/brokered-convention-republican-party-donald-trump/
[2] http://campaignstops.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/03/21/the-convention-of-76/
[3] http://capitolweekly.net/brokered-convention-republican-presidential-nomination-cleveland/
[4] http://fivethirtyeight.com/features/republican-brokered-convention-donald-trump/
[5] http://www.nytimes.com/2016/01/07/opinion/campaign-stops/how-donald-trump-loses.html
[6] http://www.nytimes.com/2016/01/14/opinion/campaign-stops/why-i-will-never-vote-for-donald-trump.html
[7] http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/19444704
[8] http://www.realclearpolitics.com/articles/2015/12/22/a_brokered_convention_in_2016_why_it_might_happen_what_it_might_mean_129119.html

Ok, I am going to keep this sporting and take the under on this one.  Here is my thinking.   Rubio, Cruse, and of course Trump are going to go to the bitter end.  Each one has the funding they need to do this, and I don't see much indication they will drop out until the convention.  Look at the vote split in Iowa.  Unless one of the three starts getting skunked in a big way, why would they drop out?  And when they go to the convention, they have all those votes they accumulated as currency to spend.  And virtually NO ONE in the republican establishment wants Trump, so unless he just kills it and gets a majority outright (subject to rules changes discussed below), the establishment will probably want a brokered convention.  They see themselves as the brokers after all.  Even if Trump just limps along and one of his major contenders move up, he will likely have enough votes to insist at a seat at the bargaining table.  And that is what Trump does for a living you know, cutting deals.  Love him or hate him, he literally wrote a book on the subject.   So for now, I am going with 35%.  If I see a clear winner I will cut my losses and increase probability.  But to the extent the field continues to be (or even becomes more) fragmented between more than two candidates, I reduce probability accordingly.     Something that is informing my thinking on this subject is that I am looking at the (albeit somewhat unreliable) polls for upcoming primaries.  Trump is strong, yes, but not dominant yet.  And I think the Florida polls are the most interesting, as they show Trump well in the lead, but not obtaining a majority.  All these polls are to be found on the internet, so I have not put in links as part of this prediction.   http://www.realclearpolitics.com/articles/2016/01/15/threat_of_brokered_convention_fuels_gop_rules_panel_129335.html

According to Wikipedia, Adlai Stevenson (of the 1952 Democratic Party) and Thomas E. Dewey (of the 1948 Republican Party) were the most recent "brokered convention" presidential nominees. Before 1936, Democratic candidates required a 2/3rds vote, making the circumstances non-comparable.  So you could argue 2 out of 40 conventions (in 80 years) at 5% base rate. 
But those cases are only likely to occur when the primary of interest is in fact a likely eligible occurrence.  Republicans changed their rules in 2012. They didn't want the unpredictability of pledged candidates secretly supporting somebody else (Ron Paul supporters were suspect). When the following was written, Christie and Rand Paul were considered regional favorites. Still too early to really say, since the first primary hasn't even happened yet, but odds are better than it seems. Party leaders have yet to coalesce around an establishment candidate (Bush, Kasich, Rubio, or Christie), because they're waiting to see who breaks out of the pack. Once the establishment coalesces around a candidate, as others drop out, then it will be more likely that the convention will only need one ballot. Once a candidate can win enough endorsements and build momentum, they will win more and more states. If no establishment candidate can build momentum during the early 4-5 primaries, and Cruz and/or Trump rack up a number of wins, then it will be more likely that the the convention will need more than one ballot.

Gotta agree with @AndrewSabisky (https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/99052) on this one. It seems like every. single. election. cycle. there is talk about a "brokered convention." This is the kind of stuff that's really good fodder for TV/movies, but it would be capital "c" CHAOS for the party befallen by it. Right now, given how *insane* the GOP looks, of course, it's tempting to predict that there'll be a brokered convention, but I'm looking at this IFP in historical context and especially noticing its launch date (right before the primaries begin!) Meaning, right now, things look *extra* hairy because there haven't actually been any votes cast (saying yes in a poll for a person is much different than casting a ballot, not to mention that these polls aren't necessarily representative because most folks in these early states haven't made up their mind, yet, but there's no need to get too deep into that here). For right now, I see zero reason to back away from 100%. I'll watch the voting in the early states, of course, and of course, things will probably still look hairy. I suspect, however, that we might start to see a leader (or a competition between two, say Cruz and Rubio), after Super Tuesday (March 1st). Until then, it's 100% for me. If you want something else to read on the matter, I suggest 538 --> Dec 10/2015: "What If Republicans Can’t Pick A Nominee Before Their Convention?" --> http://fivethirtyeight.com/features/republican-brokered-convention-donald-trump/ EDIT: fixed user handle!

Failing to secure a nominee at the first ballot points to weakness within the party, something which the GOP will surely hope to avoid. That being said, it is likely the emergence of a frontrunner in the month or two before the convention could cause many GOP members/supporters and even independents who aren't quite die-hard on who they support (that being a different candidate than the GOP frontrunner) to deviate and put support behind the frontrunner in order to gain a nomination on the first ballot, a statement of internal strength, and the first real battle cry in the direction of the Democratic Party.

Betting markets say about 80% (https://www.predictit.org/Contract/1565/Will-Republicans-have-a-brokered-convention-in-2016#openoffers) as does Nate Silver (http://fivethirtyeight.com/features/republican-brokered-convention-donald-trump/).  I'm going to go with a slightly higher estimate, based on the crowd here.
